text: you touch on a lot of things that i'm going to be talking about today so so thanks um so you know as michael said
i'm selima murshi i'm a researcher at microsoft research in the chill group which stands for
computer human interactive learning uh and i'm gonna talk to you today about some of the work that our group is doing
along with in collaboration with also a number of other folks at msr and you know some fabulous interns that
we've had on how we can work towards more usable machine learning um and you know feel
free to throughout the talk if you have questions you know just just raise your hand and let me know um so first of all you know why
why do we care about machine learning so you know we care about machine learning because we have all of this data right we have
all this data that's being collected about about us from our interactions you know on the web
or interactions with our computers and from all our sensory equipped devices and you know machine learning is
this really powerful way of sort of transforming the raw data that we have out there into usable information and so what i
mean by usable information i mean sort of a machine learned model that can be used to to make predictions um
and these these models are what we can deploy in our applications in order to automate our tasks right so we can use
them to sort of automatically detect objects or patterns and data we can use them to sort of automatically
try to organize and manage our information as well as sort of predict future behaviors
and so the way that this works at least with supervised machine learning is uh something like this where you know
given some some label data where the x's here are the data and the y's are the labels on
the data the goal is to learn some function that can predict the labels on new data
so that's that's the overall idea of supervised machine learning uh but now in practice what really happens is
there's this guy right there's a guy who's responsible for collecting some data creating some features uh and oh this is
the guy he's responsible you know getting getting the data together creating
features tweaking algorithm parameters and then sending all this information to a machine learning algorithm in order to try to learn this function
and this is you know typically an iterative process in that this guy's not going to get it right the first time right he often has to look at
how well the machine is performing and you know try to inspect what's happening and then try to improve
the model by continually trying to supply it with more and more information until it's working the way he wants it to
then the output of this process is is a model that's really encapsulating this learned function
and this model like i said you know can be deployed then in in your applications and then your applications can now you know take a new data and and can be can
use this model to make predictions so you know for example uh machine learned models are being used you know
in everything from sort of recommending interesting content to you on the web so music recommendations or you know facebook or twitter posts
um to predicting you know the relevance of ads for you even to you know like detecting fraud or
you know detecting even the outbreak of diseases the problem is that you know while
machine learning is being used for a lot of these really important tasks the models that people create are not
always accurate and that's because you know models are really a function of both a complicated
algorithm and complex data which means that you know sometimes they can predict pick up on sort of
patterns that aren't really there and those can lead to sort of bad predictions and so the consequences of you know
these sort of inaccurate models can range from you know being benign where you know you might get some you know unwanted twitter
or facebook posts or irrelevant content recommendations to really you know damaging where
financial or political decisions are being made based on inaccurate predictions or worse yet are made based on you know
predictions that might encode some inherent biases in the models
and so you know machine learning people are working on this right they're working on trying to improve machine learning algorithms
um so that they can make better predictions or make them more efficiently um and we need that uh but you know we
have to remember that there's you know also this guy right this guy is you know the one who's like providing the algorithm with
information and it is iteratively trying to debug the performance of the models that um that are being built and so you know
the ability of this guy to effectively train these algorithms really directly impacts
um the performance of the models that are being built and the problem is not that this guy doesn't have the right skills
although that can also be a problem but even machine learning experts you know have difficulty
building models or understanding exactly how their models that they build are going to perform in the wild and on on totally new data
and you know in fact you know these human limitations are something that machine learning researchers are aware of you know they try to design
algorithms to account for some of these human limit limitations themselves right so for example there's
a lot of work being done on designing algorithms that can work in the face of like noisy data or insufficient data that
might come from a human but you know there's also sort of another strategy there's a complimentary
strategy which is you know instead of trying to deal with human limitations in the algorithms
we can actually try to improve human abilities by you know trying to design new tools and interfaces in order to try to you know
reduce or prevent noisy human input altogether and you know this is what i'm going to talk
about today um i'm going to give you a couple of examples of some of the work that our group is doing uh in the space
where we're trying to sort of shift some of our attention over to the user and try to design new ways for this guy
or people to better interact with machine learning systems um so i'm going to give you a couple of
examples of this like i said so i'm going to talk first of all on about something to do with the input side which
is what we call structured labeling so it has to do with how people provide labeled data to machine learning systems um and then
i'll talk uh in the second half of the talk about the output side and so how we consider design uh better tools for people to
understand the performance of their models and then at the end i'll talk about some of the other work that our group is doing in the space and some of the
open opportunities there okay so structured labeling so this was
a project we did a couple years ago with a an intern of mine from oregon state todd kalisa
as well as several other folks at msr and just to give you a little bit of content context recall
that supervised machine learning systems learn from labeled data now oftentimes people are actually recruited
to manually label large data sets for the purpose of training these algorithms which you know seems simple enough but
the problem is that labeling data is actually not really as easy as it seems and this is something that michael talked about
right um when people label data they're they're labeling according to some target concept that's
in their heads right so for example uh imagine i was asked to label web pages
as being about cooking or not related to cooking so what i would do is i would start
labeling some examples that are you know clearly about cooking so um this is a recipe page so it
clearly has something to do with cooking here's another example then i would label some pages that are clearly
not about cooking so these are have nothing to do with sort of cooking then i might come
across a page that looks like this right so this is a page as a catering page which is you know kind of like
cooking you know um you know it kind of it's about sort of preparing food so i might say at this point that yes you
know this is about cooking then you know i'd keep going um labeling more and more examples more positive
examples and more negative examples and then i might come across a page that looks like this right so this page is
you know kind of like that catering page and that's you know it's about um someone coming to your house and preparing food for you
but you know at this point if i think about it maybe i would say that you know this is really not about cooking it's about someone else
cooking for you it's not really about the process of cooking so maybe at this point i'll say that you know this is actually not about cooking
okay so that's the problem right the problem is that i just inconsistently labeled my data
right i labeled this page as not about cooking but that previous page as about cooking and you know did i even
remember that i did that like and are there more pages like that you can imagine if you have hundreds or thousands of data points you know
will you remember that how you labeled previous examples do you need to go back and find them and move them now that you've changed your
mind about what you want to consider as part of your concept so the problem is that the concept that
people are labeling for is evolving as they observe data
and so to understand sort of how much of a problem this actually was uh we did a study where we had nine
machine learning experts label the same set of data over two sessions about four weeks apart
and what we found was that even machine learning experts were only about eighty percent
consistent with themselves on labeling the exact same set of data and in fact six out of the nine people's
um labels change significantly from one session to the next okay so so this concept evolution you
know it happens it's something that happens to the user something's happening in their heads as they label data but the tools that we
have don't allow us to sort of easily revise and refine our concepts as we go along
and this can sort of be both frustrating to the user if they want to change their minds but also can be harmful to some machine
learning algorithms that you know fundamentally assume similar items have have similar labels yes
yeah is that is that evidence of evolution which would be sort of like a changing
bias or is that just evidence of sort of randomness in my labeling yeah there's some randomness that
happens um but there's also changes and and we sort of see this in the in the study that i'll talk about
because we see that people do want to change their mind and they do move things around um and even when you when you work with
machine learning folks or people who are labeling data they often like will will use our system and then come to us and say like
well i changed my mind and i and i want to make all of those examples that i labeled for this subconcept in a different way
and really the only way they can do that is to go through every example find those or search for them somehow
and move it so so it's a bit of both um and i'll talk a little bit more about this at the end because like some some algorithms
can can actually can handle some noise um and it's actually can be good for some machine learning algorithms
whereas some algorithms are more affected by noise so so you know there there there's there's
differences there but people having people sort of understand how the label can can lower their frustration
can lower a lot of their anxiety which we also sort of found in the study um and so i'll actually show you with
the tool we came up with to sort of help people with this process um uh it's actually a technique that we call structured labeling
uh where we essentially allowed people to sort of explicitly organize uh their concept um using sort of grouping and tagging
within a traditional labeling scheme so uh what i mean by that is that instead of something like this where you
sort of force people to categorize data at a high level we had something like this where we
allowed people to create subgroups within these high-level categories so for example um if i had you know came
across this catering page and if i was unsure about it what i could do is create a subgroup for
it within the cooking category and then i can tag that subgroup maybe
with something like catering so that i could sort of remember how i labeled examples of this kind
which means that you know what that does is that it's surfacing my labeling decisions to myself so that later on
you know when i come across like other catering examples i can say that well you know this is actually very related to that other
catering page that i saw so i can group them together and then later on if i decide that maybe
catering should not be part of my concept i can easily revise uh my my concept by
moving the whole group at once um so so these groups and tags sort of you
know not only allow me to recall and revise my labeling decisions as we go along it actually lets people sort of defer my
decision make their decision making um so that's what i was sort of referring to so people often sort of agonize about like how they should label
data you know if i came across that catering page you know i might you know should this be positive should this be negative
i don't know and oftentimes people get you know very afraid of like how what their labels are going to do and so
what this does is it sort of allows people to defer their decision making right so they can tag things that they might not
be sure about and they can always go back and revise them later if they change their mind as they observe more and more data
so we also came up with an assisted version of the structured labeling tool um to sort of deal with a few problems
that we saw during a pilot study with with the tool so first of all what we noticed was that
sometimes oftentimes actually people didn't provide tags for the groups that they created um
so so you know they would sort of create these subgroups quickly you know put things aside that they weren't sure
about but they didn't want to put an effort to sort of write tags for them but then later on when they you know recall that they created a group
of something you know before they'd have to actually like look into the groups um in order to see what they had put
into all of them and you know that was a big pain so um to help people that um we provided automatic summaries um for
for the people of the groups that they created so this is just using the the text in the groups uh that people
created um just to help them sort of recall what each group was in case they didn't manually tag it
but we still allowed them to do that as well we also found that when people were
labeling they would often remember creating groups with similar items to the one that they were currently trying
to label but they would forget sort of exactly where which group they had put those similar items in
and so what we did was um we provided recommendations uh based on the similarity between the
current item a person was trying to label and the the groups that they already created um so this was this little star here
um and so that was sort of the system sort of suggesting well you put something similar like this in this group so that might
help them sort of decide where how to group things uh another interesting thing that we saw
was that you know people didn't want to sort of put in the effort to make these labeling decisions for items
that they thought were sort of outliers so you know if there's only sort of one catering example in all of my data then
it doesn't really matter whether i consider it positive or negative but it's if that example is sort of representative of a lot of a larger
con sub concept that i really want my model to recognize then i might want to put in more effort to label it
and so uh to deal with this what we did was um we we showed people similar examples um to
the example that they were currently trying to label so we would show sort of the things that the system thought thought were similar just to give them a
sense of like how sort of big this group is and whether or not they should sort of bother trying to to
structure their labels for okay so you know we did an evaluation to
understand uh to try to understand so the impacts that structured labeling had on the labeling task where we
had you know fishing participants come in we had within subjects design so we had them use each of these
different conditions the traditional labeling tool as well as the manual and assisted structured labeling tools
we had them label 100 pages and we had them label for a few different concepts that we thought people were sort of
be relatively familiar with and what we found was that you know
participants did indeed use structured labeling when it was available um we found that people created
significantly more groups in both the structured labeling conditions than compared to the traditional labeling where they couldn't
do that but interestingly we we noticed that people tended to create fewer but larger groups
with the assisted condition and that's probably because the system was making recommendations about where
where the subgroups were or where how they should create these subgroups based on their previous um labeling
decisions uh we also found that you know people revised and revisited uh their labels
significantly more with the structured labeling tools than with the traditional tools so this sort of gets back to the ideas like is
it noise or are people sort of really trying to change their minds or or wanting to sort of understand their
labeling decisions so people were looking back and they were trying to change things as when they were when they had a tool that
allowed them to do so um so we also looked at like the consistency of people's labels
uh and found that uh with both structured labeling tools uh people uh labeled significantly more
consistently than with the traditional labeling tool with no real significance difference between the manual and the
assisted conditions so you know this is this is great this is what we wanted um
but uh the the consistency and the ability to evolve your concept
did come at a cost right it actually took people longer to complete the labeling task with the
structured labeling conditions which you know makes sense because people are putting you know they have to
do more work they have to create these subgroups and decide decide how to tag them and which groups to create but
interestingly when we looked at sort of the difference in how long it took people to label uh in the first half of the study versus
the second half we saw that this difference in speed uh really decreased and this was likely due to people sort
of converging after a while on on what they wanted the definition of their concept to be so there's some upfront cost to having
the structure but it decreases over time we also found that you know people
preferred the structured labeling condition for most tasks saying that you know it helped them to sort of organize the items that they they wanted
to label um interestingly uh in terms of the assisted condition
some people said that they preferred it because it actually sort of converted a decision-making task into sort of a
verification one right so with the with the recommendations the user can say like well you know actually i want it to be
somewhere else instead of having to decide how they want to label um and you know of course you know there
some people did say that they they prefer the traditional tool because you know it's simple um but those p a lot of those people you
know wanted the structured labeling tool in certain cases where they were sort of less familiar with their concept right
so if you know exactly what you want to be what you want to include as positive or negative examples then
maybe you don't need a structured labeling tool but if you know you're sort of more fuzzy on the concept then then having something like this they
thought would be helpful okay so um to summarize you know people
you know people evolve their concepts as they observe data but the current tools that people have you know don't
allow them to sort of revise and recall their decision making and so we proposed this this technique
called structure labeling to help them and found that you know people did use it and it helped improve uh
help them label more consistently and so sort of going back to the consistency issue like i said um some algorithms are more affected by
labeling inconsistency than others uh particularly like highly expressive algorithms um
can try to overfit to the to the noise and the data and so they may be more effective than less expressive ones
um but even regardless this is something that's you know happening to the user right so the it's causing frustration to the user
if they want to change their mind about how they want their algorithms to behave so something that's still happening
that can still benefit the labelers themselves and the structure also itself
contains information right it contains information that you can use in order to so you know come up with
features for example that can sort of help your algorithm learn about sort of these sub-concepts it contains information you know we can
we can sort of measure the performance of your model on each of the different subclusters which can help you sort of
make decisions about what you want to include or or not so there's a lot of actual information that's contained within
these these groups and tags that we can also use in order to try to improve the performance of the models that we build
um okay so i mean other questions about structured labeling so this is just sort of one way that we're trying to help
help people better interact with machine learning systems um i'm gonna talk about uh sort of the
output side after that if they're there are no questions right now we could also have questions at the end
okay um i'll keep going uh so so uh model tracker um has to do
with the output side of this process um which is sort of you know this when people are for building models they need
to sort of understand the performance of the models in order to try to iterate and so you know
what happens in this process is that when you're building a model the output that you see in every
iteration should directly influence your subsequent actions right that's that's
really the idea of seeing sort of performance results if your model is performing poorly then you're going to try to go in and fix it
the problem is that most of the time what we see at the stage is something like this right some number
that summarizes the overall performance of your model the problem is that you know what does
that really tell you right it can signal that there is a problem but it doesn't really tell you anything
about you know where those problems are or how you should deal with them or what you should deal with first and even if you're lucky and if you have
several summary statistics or you know the the sort of standard uh confusion matrices or prediction
precision recall curves sort of the standard techniques that people use to understand the performance of their models
all of these techniques convey the existence of errors but they don't tell you where those those errors are or what you should do
about that them and you know for that uh what you usually have to do is actually switch to you know a
different tool or a different mode to actually like pull up your data or visualize your errors
um and these types of tools are often you know heavy heavyweight meaning that you often have to sort of convert your
data into different form and then use a different tool to visualize and even if you have like a a tool that
that can do that once you've loaded up your data you still have to sort of sort and filter in order to find errors and then try to
gain insights about what the problems might be so the problem is that this you know
switching between these summary statistics to heavyweight tools for debugging can
actually be very disruptive to your primary task which is to build a model
and in fact you know this problem has been shown um to lead to a trial and error approach to
model building meaning that um people instead of like looking at their data at every iteration to try to see what's
happening they will randomly try to change parameters of their model tweak parameters or add features
in order to try to make these summary statistics go up right and then only when that fails then will they actually sort of resort to
looking at their data and trying to sort of understand what's really going on
so the model tracker project was really you know us trying to figure out how we could sort of encourage people or enable people to take a more informed approach
to model building um so i will

this okay cool um okay so
let me go back so it's a little bit slow okay so so this is um this whole system is
called ice interactive classification and extraction um and this is a platform that our group at msr is
building um to enable non-experts to build classifiers and entity extractors
over big data um in you know one sitting in a few hours um and so you know i won't be able to
talk a lot about it today but you know for the purposes of this talk just you just need to know this is that up here is where you would like
label data so i could say these are positive or negative um and submit data to my model and over
on the left is where a person can sort of provide features for for their models to learn with
now um in this case i've already built a model using ice so i've i've tried to train a classifier to
recognize whether web pages are about cycling or not cycling so in this
case i've already labeled about 511 items and provided six features
now in ice what we used to have are is what you see here below these are the
sort of summaries standard summary statistics and graphs that you might use when you're using trying to use machine learning so
people sort of would interact with their system label data create features and then look at these summary statistics in order to
try to see what's going on and then when they thought there was a problem they would switch over to a review mode
where they could do things like sort and filter so they could filter by errors
and it's a little bit slow but they'll pull up sort of the data that's that you've already labeled that's in error and then you can sort of
page through those those items in order to try to sort of gain some insights and understand what's going on
this should be pulling up data but it's a little slow but you get the idea um so uh what we did in this project was
um replace all of these standard summary statistics and graphs with this single visualization which you
see here below which we call model tracker so i'll explain what it's showing
so each of these little boxes corresponds to an example that i've already labeled so in this case i've labeled 511
examples so there's 511 boxes the color of the box is the label that i
gave so if i said something was positive it's going to be green if i said something is negative it's going to be red
now the boxes are laid out horizontally according to my classifier score with low scoring
examples to the left and high scoring examples to the right so what that means is what i want this
visualization to look like is i want all my green boxes to be on the right and all my red boxes to be on
the left right because that would mean that my system is very much agreeing with with what i told it to
um and it similarly errors are also visible in this way because errors are the red boxes that are
to the right so red boxes that are that are getting uh high scores and green boxes that are shown to the
left so what this is doing is it's showing me performance right it's showing me where
my errors are but unlike with summary statistics that sort of treat all errors equally
this is actually showing me not only my errors but it's showing me sort of the severity of my
errors where more severe sort of errors more egregious errors are sort of the ones that are at the far ends of these
visual the visualization because that's where the system and i very much disagree as
opposed to sort of this uncertain middle area where where the system is sort of more confused so what that does is it allows people to
sort of prioritize their efforts in debugging um and you know in addition you know because we're showing data at the item
level you can actually click on these right you can actually like click on them to to pull up the errors directly so it's providing you direct
access to your data so you don't have to go search for for problems um and then try to sort of
gain some insights from them and figure out what's going on so for in this case you know i clicked on this
this green box which is at the far left corner so the something i labeled as positive but the system's giving a really low score
um and this page you know so i was trying to create a classifier that can recognize whether a page is about cycling
or not this is actually a recycling page so that i actually label this positive so
that's that's actually a mislabel on my part and that actually happens quite often so what i can do
is directly change it so i can change my label update my model and then the system will
uh retrain possibly and uh it would update this
visualization once it like retrained um so again you'll have to imagine but like it would fix the error and then
the the visualization would try would update um and to yeah some something's not like
or something's failing but that's the idea the idea is you can directly access the errors and and sort of look at them
um and then try to sort of fix them as you go along yes
examples yeah so um if you notice like so when i click on these boxes you see these lines that are
showing up connecting the item that i clicked on to other examples um it's actually showing me and it will
pull up the other examples that i'm connected to so it's showing me examples that the system thinks is very similar in my current
feature space and the idea behind that was that if there are examples that you label differently but
the system sees as very much the same in the feature space that likely means that there's a feature
problem it's you're seeing something that the system is not seeing because it thinks these two are very different
so in that case you know that can give you information about how to debug and then you might you can add a feature in order to try to fix your error and i
would show that now but i'm afraid it won't like update so maybe i can show a little video at the
end um just to give you a sense of what the update looks like um so so so that's what model tracker shows
um but so i want to explain that also model tracker actually subsumes the same information that we
see in all of these summary statistics and graphs so so i want to explain that so first of
all confusion matrices um so are people familiar with confusion matrices okay
so so confusion matrices um you know we're just showing you the agreements and disagreements between um
your labels and the system's predictions right so things that i labeled as positive in this case there's 34 examples that i
labeled as positive that the system also thinks is possible positive but there are seven examples
that are in error seven examples that i said was positive and the system said was negative so showing you
agreements and disagreements model tracker you also see agreements and disagreements you're seeing you know errors um
disagreements are red boxes to the right and green boxes to the left and agreements are our green boxes to
the right and red boxes to the left but now unlike with confusion matrices
which are threshold dependent model tracker is actually threshold independent so what do i mean so so for to create a confusion matrix you
have to set a threshold right so if i wanted to sort of see the performance of my model at a different threshold i would actually have to
change the threshold so that we have a slider here that allows us to do that and then you would be able to generate a
new confusion matrix matrix to see sort of what the performance is at that threshold
um with model tracker you can see the performance um at all thresholds at once so you can see that you know so
we have a threshold line here but actually it doesn't serve any functional purpose it just serves as a visual aid
and so what it can do is like if i you know if i move my my threshold to the right i can see that
you know i'm reducing the number of false positives because i have fewer red boxes to the right
but it's coming at a cost of false negatives because now i have more green boxes that are to the to the left
so you can sort of see the trade-off between your false positives and false negatives that your agreements and disagreements
at all thresholds at once so if you wanted to see the sort of same information with confusion matrices you
know you would need one of these for each threshold that you're interested in which you know can be up to like a hundred
um model tracker also shows you the same information that you would see in precision recall curves
um are people familiar with precision recalculation you know
is um it's the number of true positives over the number of true
positives and false positives and recall is sort of the number the true positives over
um true positives and false negatives something like that and you know if that's confusing you know don't worry because it's confusing for everybody like it's
even even machine learning experts i i often see sort of trying to do this mental mapping in their head like
so precision is is this over this and what does that actually translate to um with model tracker you can actually
see this um directly so um precision and model tracker are the number of green boxes that are to the
right of this threshold line right so in this case you know i'm doing i'm doing pretty well in terms of precision because most of
what you see on the right is is positive but recall so recall is
the number of green boxes that are to the right and so there's a lot of green boxes that the system is predicting as negative so
i'm actually doing pretty bad in terms of recall and so you can actually see the the precision recall trade off at the
various thresholds as well because you know if i were to move my threshold line to the left
i'd be increasing recall because you know more green boxes are being predicted as positive
but it's clearly coming at a cost of precision because now also more false i'm predicting more red boxes
as positive um so you can see see all of that as well so you can see sort of what what
the standard precision recall curves will show you um so subsuming all of the information
that we would normally see but also providing you direct access to your errors so that we can sort of encourage people to look at their data
and understand what's going on with every iteration we also do a whole bunch of other things like because you're showing data at the
item level you can do you can do a lot of annotations to this so you might notice some of these annotations i have here so
i've sort of tagged items that i want to sort of keep track of and so you know as i'm going along if i try to fix
those errors i might want to tag it to see if it actually got fixed as a result of my action so i can do that you see these little
circles here those are showing me sort of outliers this isn't what the system thinks are outliers so that can sort of give me
additional debugging information if i look at one of those i might be able to i might see that maybe
um it's showing me something that it's only seen one example of this kind so i might need to provide more examples
you know we can also show feature information so if i hover over these features i can sort of see how that feature is correlated with my
class so that can sort of help me sort of debug at the feature level so there's a lot of things we can do because we're showing data at the item
level okay so so that's model tracker um

if it's learning as you go you'll sort of see these these classes sort of separate you'd see like green boxes moving to the right and red box to the
